content.webTitle: Sellafield 'riddled with safety flaws', according to BBC investigation

fields.headline: Sellafield 'riddled with safety flaws', according to BBC investigation
fields.bodyText: The Sellafield nuclear site is riddled with potentially lethal safety flaws, according to a BBC investigation. The Panorama programme, broadcast on Monday night, uncovered a raft of safety issues on the site in Cumbria which stores almost all of the country’s nuclear waste. The investigation was prompted by a whistleblower, once a senior manager in Sellafield, who revealed a litany of safety concerns including degraded infrastructure, improper storage of highly radioactive materials and chronic under staffing across the site. Speaking anonymously, he told the programme he worried about the safety of the site “every day”. Panorama revealed how radioactive chemicals are stored in plastic bottles on the site that should only ever have been used as short-term storage. Despite the efforts of scientists at Sellafield to try to eradicate the problem, the probe found more than 2,000 bottles with the toxic materials still on site. Dr Rex Strong, head of nuclear safety at Sellafield, said: “The organisation is now focusing on putting right some underinvestments of the past in order to support the hazard and waste reduction mission that the site has.” Sellafield later said in a statement that plutonium and uranium samples were “kept securely” and that “to imply that such material is inappropriately managed is simply not true”. The whistleblower said that his biggest fear for the site was for one of the nuclear waste silos to go up in flames – the consequences of which would be dire. He said: “If there is a fire there it could generate a plume of radiological waste that will go across western Europe.” It was also revealed that swaths of the plant often do not have enough staff to meet basic safety levels. Investigators for the programme found that in the space of 12 months between July 2012 and July 2013, minimum levels of safe manning levels were routinely breached. However Strong insisted that low staffing levels did not mean safety was compromised. He said: “You make alternative arrangements, so the things that have to be done, get done, and facilities are shut down if in fact we’re not able to operate them in the way that we want to – it’s not a level that’s dangerous.” One report on the site’s infrastructure from 2013 featured on the programme said “years of neglect” had lead to “intolerable conditions” in Sellafield. The programme makers linked an incident in the plant in 2013 to the crumbling infrastructure when an electricity substation exploded, leading to radioactive dust spreading into parts of the building. Sellafield’s press office did not respond to repeated attempts to contact it on Monday night. However, a statement given to the programme the Nuclear Management Partners, who ran Sellafield until earlier this year, said the safety and security of the site have always been their “overriding priorities” and that over the past eight years the site achieved “the best overall safety … in its history.” Strong added: “There’s been huge and sustained investment in infrastructure at Sellafield over recent years. Safety is our priority and we are managing a very complex site which has got a great deal of hazardous radioactive materials on it.” • This article was amended on 6 September 2016. An earlier version said Nuclear Management Partners ran Sellafield. The contract to own and operate Sellafield was transferred back to the Nuclear Decommissioning Authority in March.
